title: 104_hr1404
content: The policy of the United States aims to end animal suffering caused by steel jaw leghold traps by prohibiting their shipment in interstate or foreign commerce, along with fur articles from animals trapped in such traps. The Act defines "article of fur" as any furskin or article containing furskin, and clarifies terms related to furskin. It also defines "interstate or foreign commerce" and "import" in alignment with existing laws. The term "steel jaw leghold trap" is defined as a spring-powered device with two steel jaws designed to capture an animal by snapping closed on its limb. The term "person" includes individuals, partnerships, corporations, and government entities. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. PROHIBITED ACTS AND PENALTIES. No fur article can be traded if derived from an animal trapped in a steel jaw leghold trap. It is illegal to import, export, or use such traps in interstate or foreign commerce. Violators will face penalties under regulations set by the Secretary. Violators of subsection (a) or (b) or related regulations may be fined up to $1,000 for the first offense and up to $5,000 and two years imprisonment for subsequent violations. The Secretary will pay half of the fine to anyone providing information leading to a conviction under this Act. Government officials are not eligible for rewards. Enforcement measures are outlined in Section 5. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges and magistrates can issue warrants for enforcement. Individuals can detain, search, and seize packages and make arrests without a warrant for violations. The Secretary enforces the Act and regulations with the help of other agencies. Judges and magistrates can issue warrants for enforcement. Individuals can detain, search, and seize packages, make arrests without a warrant for violations, and execute warrants or criminal processes. Seized items will be held pending criminal proceedings or forfeiture actions, with the option for the owner to post a bond. Upon forfeiture to the United States, items will be disposed of by the Secretary in a manner consistent with the Act's purposes. Any fur or steel jaw leghold trap taken, possessed, sold, purchased, transported, delivered, carried, shipped, exported, or imported contrary to the Act or regulations shall be subject to forfeiture. The Attorney General may seek to enjoin violators. The Secretary will create regulations to enforce the Act, which will take effect one year after enactment.
